questions.text: A patient presents with gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms according to the given fundoscopic image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is a progressive eye disease characterized by the loss of night vision (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision, often described as "tunnel vision." The disease involves the degeneration of photoreceptor cells in the retina, primarily affecting the rods, which are responsible for low-light vision.

 

The characteristic fundoscopic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa include:

 

  1. Black pigmentary deposits (bone spicule appearance) – These are seen around the periphery of the retina.
  2. Vascular attenuation – Retinal vessels are thinned out, indicating decreased blood flow.
  3. Waxy pallor of the optic disc – This is a pale appearance of the optic disc due to retinal degeneration.

 

The fundoscopic image shows black pigmentation and attenuated vessels, which are classic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fundus flavimaculatus: This condition is a variant of Stargardt disease and primarily involves the macula, showing yellowish flecks in the retina. This condition is associated with chromosome 1 and mutations in the ABCA4 gene.

 

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the retina, often appearing as red patches or dots. It does not cause a gradual loss of night vision or tunnel vision and is not associated with black pigmentary changes.

 

 

Option D. Fundus Albipunctatus: This condition is characterized by white, dot-like lesions scattered across the retina and may also present with night vision problems. However, it lacks the black pigmentation and vascular attenuation seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa, making it an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is identified by a triad of symptoms: black pigmentary deposits, vascular attenuation, and waxy pallor of the optic disc, accompanied by nyctalopia and tunnel vision.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are true about optic neuritis? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

I. Disproportionate loss of colour vision and contrast to visual acuity
II. 70% cases of multiple sclerosis are affected
III. Treatment is done by oral steroids
IV. Optic neuritis presents with normal fundus or disc edema
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only IV

 

  • Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve that can present in different forms. 
  • Statement IV is correct because optic neuritis can present as either papillitis (with disc edema visible on fundoscopy) or retrobulbar neuritis (with a normal-appearing fundus). 
  • In retrobulbar neuritis, which is the most frequent type in adults and commonly associated with multiple sclerosis, the inflammation occurs behind the eyeball, resulting in the classic description "neither the patient sees anything nor the doctor sees anything" - meaning there's vision loss but the optic disc appears normal. 
  • In papillitis, there is hyperemia and edema of the optic nerve head visible on examination. Neuroretinitis, the least common type, shows a macular star pattern of exudates.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement I - Disproportionate loss of colour vision: This is incorrect. Optic neuritis actually causes proportionate loss of vision, not disproportionate. Patients experience sudden onset vision loss, decreased color vision (particularly red desaturation), and may have a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), but these changes are proportional to the degree of optic nerve damage.

 

Statement II - 70% cases of multiple sclerosis are affected: This is incorrect. The correct statistics are: 50% of multiple sclerosis patients will experience an attack of optic neuritis during their lifetime, not 70%. Additionally, 10-15% of patients with multiple sclerosis present initially with optic neuritis as their first symptom.

 

Statement III - Treatment is done by oral steroids: This is incorrect. According to the Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT), the standard treatment is intravenous methylprednisolone (1g/day for 3 days) followed by oral steroids (1mg/kg/day for 11 days). Direct oral steroids without initial IV therapy are actually contraindicated as they may increase the risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic neuritis can present with either a normal fundus (retrobulbar neuritis) or disc edema (papillitis), and treatment requires initial IV steroids, not oral steroids alone.

 

Note - Optic Neuritis:

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: Which nutrient deficiency is cause of night blindness? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Night blindness, or nyctalopia, is a common symptom of vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment found in the retina that is necessary for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency does not typically cause night blindness. Vitamin C is important for overall health, but it is not directly involved in the visual process.

 

Option C. Vitamin B: Vitamin B deficiencies, such as vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, can lead to various neurological symptoms but are not known to cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency primarily affects bone health and calcium metabolism. It is not associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ptosis

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that affects the cranial muscles, including the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs).
  • Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints in MG.
  • Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in MG.
  • The cranial muscles are typically involved early in the course of MG.
  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized.
  • Patients who only experience weakness in the EOMs for 3 years are said to have ocular MG.

 

Tensilon test:

 

In Myasthenia, there is improvement of ptosis with IV inj. of Edrophonium (Tensilon).

 

 

Lagophthalmos and Exophthalmos are signs of Thyroid Eye Disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diplopia: Common in MG but less frequent than ptosis.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos: Inability to close the eyelids completely, typically associated with thyroid eye disease or facial nerve palsy, not common in MG.

 

Option C. Exophthalmos: Protrusion of the eyeball, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease, not MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common ocular finding in Myasthenia Gravis, a neuromuscular disorder characterized by antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Congested vessels cannot be moved with a cotton bud

questions.text: Which of the following is indicative of episcleritis rather than scleritis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine

 

Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine is characteristic of episcleritis and helps differentiate it from scleritis. This occurs because:

 

  • In episcleritis, the inflammation affects the episcleral vessels which are superficial
  • These superficial vessels constrict in response to topical vasoconstrictors like phenylephrine
  • This vasoconstrictive response results in blanching of the redness
  • The deeper vessels involved in scleritis are not affected by topical vasoconstrictors

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Severe Pain:

 

  • Severe pain is characteristic of scleritis, not episcleritis
  • Episcleritis typically causes mild discomfort or irritation
  • Scleritis pain is often described as deep, boring, and may wake the patient at night
  • The pain in scleritis may radiate to the temple and forehead

 

Options B. Tenderness:

 

  • Marked tenderness on palpation is typical of scleritis
  • Episcleritis shows minimal or no tenderness
  • The tenderness in scleritis corresponds to the area of inflammation
  • This tenderness is due to deeper inflammation affecting scleral tissue

 

Options C. Congested vessels cannot be moved with a cotton bud:

 

  • Immobile vessels are characteristic of scleritis
  • In episcleritis, the vessels are superficial and can be moved with a cotton bud
  • The immobility in scleritis occurs because the inflammation is within the scleral tissue
  • This is a useful clinical test to differentiate between the two conditions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blanching of vessels with vasoconstrictors like phenylephrine is a key diagnostic feature of episcleritis, distinguishing it from scleritis which shows no blanching due to deeper vessel involvement.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child who was born premature at 34 weeks POG weighing 1400 gms presents with leukocoria. On CT, intraocular calcification is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Explanation:

 

While the history of prematurity (34 weeks) and low birth weight (1400g) might suggest ROP, the presence of intraocular calcification on CT scan is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood, and it is the only condition among the given options that shows intraocular calcification. This calcification can be detected on CT scan, though CT is generally avoided due to radiation exposure risks. The preferred imaging modalities are ultrasound B-scan and contrast-enhanced MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity): While the premature birth and low birth weight are risk factors for ROP, it does not present with intraocular calcification. ROP occurs in newborns <34 weeks or <2.0 kg birth weight and presents with abnormal vessel development.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This presents as leukocoria but does not show intraocular calcification. It is an opacity of the natural lens that is present at birth.

 

Option D. Coat's Disease: While this can present with leukocoria, it is characterized by retinal telangiectasia and exudation without calcification. It typically affects young males and is usually unilateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraocular calcification seen on imaging in a child with leukocoria is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma, regardless of other clinical factors like prematurity.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: A patient presents with reduced visual acuity that improves on looking through pin hole. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Refractive error

 

The pinhole test is a simple and effective way to differentiate between refractive errors and other causes of reduced visual acuity. When a patient looks through a pinhole, it blocks out all but the central rays of light, which are less likely to be deflected by refractive errors. This allows the light to focus more accurately on the retina, often leading to an improvement in visual acuity if the underlying problem is a refractive error.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Refractive errors: These include myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism. These conditions result from the eye's inability to properly focus light onto the retina, causing blurred vision. The pinhole test improves vision in cases of refractive errors because it allows only the central light rays to enter, bypassing the refractive error.
  • Retinal and macular diseases: These conditions affect the retina or the macula directly and are not typically corrected by the pinhole test. Examples include macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal detachment.
  • Astigmatism: Although astigmatism is a type of refractive error, it is more specifically characterized by an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, leading to blurred vision at all distances. The pinhole test can still improve vision in astigmatism by focusing light rays more accurately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinal diseases: Conditions affecting the retina, such as diabetic retinopathy or retinal detachment, do not improve with the pinhole test because the underlying issue is with the retina itself, not the refraction of light.

 

Option C. Macular diseases: Diseases affecting the macula, such as age-related macular degeneration, also do not improve with the pinhole test for the same reason.

 

Option D. Astigmatism: While astigmatism is a refractive error and can improve with the pinhole test, the answer "Refractive error" (option A) is more comprehensive, as it includes astigmatism along with myopia and hyperopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pinhole test is a useful diagnostic tool that improves visual acuity in patients with refractive errors by allowing only the central rays of light to reach the retina, thereby bypassing the refractive defects. This test does not improve vision in cases of retinal or macular diseases.

questions.text: Acute sudden painful diminution of vision with vertically oval pupil is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Angle closure glaucoma

 

Angle closure glaucoma is a condition where there is a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the closure of the angle between the iris and the cornea, which obstructs the drainage of aqueous humor. This leads to a rapid rise in IOP, resulting in acute, severe eye pain, headache, nausea, and a sudden loss of vision. A key clinical sign of an acute angle closure glaucoma attack is a mid-dilated, vertically oval, and sluggishly reacting pupil. The vertically oval pupil occurs due to ischemia of the iris sphincter muscles caused by the high IOP.

 

 

This condition is an ophthalmic emergency, and immediate treatment is necessary to prevent permanent vision loss. The high IOP can cause damage to the optic nerve, leading to irreversible vision loss if not promptly managed.

 

Note - Vogt's triad is a set of three clinical signs associated with the aftermath of an acute attack of glaucoma. This triad includes sphincter atrophy (damage to the iris sphincter muscle), a mid-dilated pupil that does not react well to light, and glaucoma flecken, which are patches of pigmentation or discoloration on the lens of the eye resulting from the damage caused by the increased intraocular pressure during a glaucoma attack.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR/Macular degeneration: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) and age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) are conditions that cause a gradual, painless loss of central vision. They do not present with acute pain, sudden vision loss, or pupillary abnormalities like a vertically oval pupil.

 

Option B. Cataract: Cataracts cause a gradual, painless decrease in vision due to the clouding of the lens. They do not cause sudden vision loss, pain, or changes in pupil shape.

 

Option C. Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause sudden vision loss and pain, particularly with eye movement. However, it does not cause changes in the shape of the pupil or a vertically oval pupil. The pain in optic neuritis is typically associated with eye movements rather than the constant severe pain seen in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute angle closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss, and a mid-dilated, vertically oval, sluggishly reacting pupil. Recognizing these signs is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with complaints of severe pain, redness, photophobia, and blurring of vision for more than two weeks, not responding to standard treatment. On examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrates and overlying epithelial defects is observed in the affected eye. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba keratitis

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Acanthamoeba keratitis. 
  • The key diagnostic features include:
    • History of contact lens use (most common risk factor)
    • Severe pain that is disproportionate to clinical signs
    • Ring infiltrate in the cornea (pathognomonic sign)
    • Non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy
    • Chronicity of symptoms (over two weeks)

 

Supporting Evidence:

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis presents with characteristic ring infiltrates, central or paracentral, with overlying epithelial defects. The most common predisposing factor is contact lens wear, particularly with improper lens hygiene or exposure to contaminated water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial keratitis:

 

  • Typically responds to antibiotics within days
  • Pain is proportionate to clinical signs
  • Most common organism in contact lens users is Pseudomonas (causes hypopyon ulcer)
  • Does not characteristically form ring infiltrates
  • Usually has quicker onset and progression

 

Option C. Viral keratitis:

 

  • Characterized by dendritic or geographic patterns (herpes simplex)
  • Usually has reduced corneal sensations
  • Responds to antiviral therapy
  • Does not form ring-shaped infiltrates
  • Often has history of recurrence

 

Option D. Fungal keratitis:

 

  • Typically has history of vegetative matter injury
  • Shows feathery margins with satellite lesions
  • Cheesy necrotic appearance of ulcer base
  • May have Wessley immune ring but not typical ring infiltrates as seen in Acanthamoeba
  • Signs are usually more prominent than symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring-shaped stromal infiltrates in a contact lens wearer with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs and non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy is pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Vogt's triad in primary angle closure glaucoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Goniosynechiae

 

Vogt's triad is seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute primary angle closure (PAC). It is specifically characterized by three distinct features: glaukomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity), patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy. Goniosynechiae (peripheral anterior synechiae) are not part of Vogt's triad, though they are common findings in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iris atrophy: This is a component of Vogt's triad. Patches of iris atrophy occur due to ischemic damage during the acute attack and represent one of the three classic findings.

 

Option C. Non-reacting pupil: This is a component of Vogt's triad. The slightly dilated, non-reactive pupil results from sphincter atrophy caused by ischemia during the acute attack.

 

Option D. Glaukomflecken: These are correctly described as part of Vogt's triad. Glaukomflecken are anterior subcapsular lenticular opacities that develop following an acute attack of angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad consists of glaukomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity), patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non reacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy—it is a classic finding following an attack of acute primary angle closure glaucoma, while goniosynechiae represent a different pathological finding in this condition.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

 

Explanation : 


Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.


Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period,  presenting  5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.

 


Other Options:

 

Option B. Gonorrhea: Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.

 

Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 
 

 

(REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

questions.text: In which of the following is atropine contraindicated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute congestive glaucoma

 

The use of atropine is not recommended in cases of acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of increasing intraocular pressure.

 

  • Since atropine is a mydriatic, it may lead to the obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, causing a sudden increase in intraocular pressure.
  • Dim light can also precipitate an attack.
    • Atropine may be indicated as a cycloplegic agent to alleviate pain and prevent synechiae formation in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.
    • In malignant glaucoma, atropine can be the initial management option.
    • In corneal ulcers, atropine is used as an adjuvant therapy, to reduce pain induced by ciliary muscle spasm via its cycloplegic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute anterior uveitis: Atropine is actually beneficial in cases of acute anterior uveitis. It helps to relieve pain by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing the formation of posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and the lens), which can complicate uveitis.

 

Option C. Malignant glaucoma: In malignant glaucoma, atropine might be used as part of the management strategy to try to break the attack by deepening the anterior chamber and pulling the lens-iris diaphragm backward.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: Atropine is used in the treatment of corneal ulcers to provide comfort by relieving the painful ciliary spasm and to prevent synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine should be used cautiously, and is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma due to its potential to exacerbate the condition by further increasing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (-2D in right eye and +1D in left eye) in a 6-year-old child with normal visual acuity and retinal findings on fundus examination, is suggestive of: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anisometropia

 

Explanation:

 

Anisometropia refers to a significant difference in refractive power between the two eyes. In this case:

 

  • The right eye has myopia (-2D).
  • The left eye has hypermetropia (+1D).
  • This meets the criteria for anisometropia, which is defined as a difference of at least 2.5 diopters between the two eyes.
  • A difference in refractive errors between both eyes leads to different image sizes (anisokonia).
  • If untreated, the brain may suppress the image from one eye, potentially leading to anisometropic amblyopia.
  • It can be corrected using glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mixed Astigmatism:

 

  • In mixed astigmatism, both myopia and hypermetropia occur within the same eye, affecting different meridians.
  • This patient has different refractive errors in each eye, not within the same eye.

 

Option C. Myopia:

 

  • Myopia (near-sightedness) occurs when light focuses in front of the retina, causing blurred distance vision.
  • Since the left eye is hypermetropic, this case is not pure myopia.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia:

 

  • Hypermetropia (far-sightedness) occurs when light focuses behind the retina, making near vision more difficult.
  • Since the right eye is myopic, the child does not have bilateral hypermetropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is a condition where the two eyes have significantly different refractive errors, which can lead to amblyopia if untreated. Early correction with spectacles or contact lenses is essential to prevent visual impairment.

questions.text: A patient of HIV with low CD4 count presents with the following finding. Which of the following is used in the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ganciclovir

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a case of retinitis, a common ocular manifestation in HIV patients with low CD4 counts.

 

Retinitis can be caused by various pathogens, but in the context of HIV with a low CD4 count, Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is a significant concern. This condition is typically seen when the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/mm³. CMV retinitis presents with retinal necrosis and can progress rapidly, leading to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice for CMV retinitis is Ganciclovir, which can be administered intravitreally to deliver the drug directly to the affected site in the eye. Ganciclovir inhibits viral replication by targeting viral DNA polymerase, making it effective against CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: This antiviral is used primarily for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) infections.

 

Option B. Valacyclovir: This is a prodrug of acyclovir and is also used for HSV and VZV infections.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: This antiviral is used in the treatment of HIV and Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for CMV retinitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, administered intravitreally to manage the infection effectively and prevent blindness.
